It requires a hot and warm climate. Green gram is considered to be hardiest among all pulse crops and can tolerate drought to a great extent. Green gram is also used as a green manure and fodder crop.

questionText: Which of the following is the chief characteristic of 'mixed farming'?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Mixed farming is a system of farming in agriculture, which involves the growing or cultivation of crops and rearing of animals (livestock) on the same piece of land, on a particular season. This system of farming is practised all around the world, it helps to ensure sustainable agriculture. A mixed farm may grow cereal like maize, wheat and also rear cattle, pig and poultry. A few advantages of mixed farming are: In mixed farming, all products are utilised. Money is saved as there is reduced cost of feeding farm animals and reduced or no cost of fertiliser application. If a crop does poorly in a season, the farmer can fall back on income from sales of meat, milk and eggs.

options.text: Cultivation of both cash crops and food crops
Cultivation of two or more crops in the same field
Rearing of animals and cultivation of crops together

questionText: Among the following states, which one has the most suitable climatic conditions for the cultivation of a large variety of orchids with minimum cost of production, and can develop an export-oriented industry in this field?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: There are more than 1,300 species of orchids found in India, primarily in the Northeast: Assam, Meghalaya, and Arunachal Pradesh and also in Sikkim and south India. Most orchids are perennial herbs with simple leaves and if raised in the right conditions (temperature not less than 16-17°C), they should last eight weeks with flowers, after which the blooms slowly start dropping off. Among all the states, Arunachal Pradesh has the most suitable climatic conditions for the cultivation of a large variety of orchids with minimum cost of production and can develop an export-oriented industry in this field.

questionText:
A state in India has the following characteristics:
1. Its northern part is arid and semi-arid.
2. Its central part produces cotton.
3. Cultivation of cash crops is predominant over food crops.
Which one of the following states has all of the above characteristics?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: The northern arid regions in India comprised largely the desert of Rajasthan, the Rann of Kutch and the semi-arid regions of Punjab and Gujarat. The Southern arid regions are in the rain shadow of the Western Ghats covering states of Maharashtra, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. In India, majority of the cotton production comes from nine major cotton growing states, which are grouped into three diverse agro-ecological zones, as under: Northern Zone: Punjab, Haryana, and Rajasthan; Central Zone: Gujarat, Maharashtra, and Madhya Pradesh; Southern Zone: Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, and Karnataka. The economy of Gujarat is largely dependent upon agriculture. More than 50 percent of the total available production is cash crop. The main food crops are bajra, jowar, rice and wheat. Major commercial crops or cash crops are groundnut, tobacco and cotton, linseed, sugarcane, etc. Gujarat is the state where cultivation of cash crops is predominant over food crops.

questionText:
With reference to micro-irrigation, which of the following statements is/are correct?
1. Fertiliser/nutrient loss can be reduced.
2. It is the only means of irrigation in dry land farming.
3. In some areas of farming, receding of the groundwater table can be checked.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Micro-irrigation is the process of slow application of water to the soil so that moisture is retained in the upper layer rather than percolating underground or causing surface run-off. Micro-irrigation can increase yields and decrease water, fertiliser, and labour requirements. Using Micro-irrigation fertiliser or nutrient loss can be reduced as less water is applied hence fertilisers are easily absorbed into plants. Moreover, by applying water directly to the root zone, the practice reduces loss of water through conveyance, run-off, deep percolation, and evaporation. It is not the only means of irrigation in dry land farming. Micro Irrigation can be applied to any form of land because it saves water in Irrigation. Agriculture consumes the largest share of groundwater in India - the biggest user of groundwater in the world. The past few decades have witnessed an alarming depletion of groundwater resources in the country. While almost half of the agricultural area cultivating food grains in India depends on irrigation, as high as 65 percent of these irrigated land holdings depend on groundwater to meet their water needs. It has been recommended that farmers should move from flood irrigation to drip or sprinkler irrigation systems (micro-irrigation). This will help in conserving groundwater as well as save on the cost of irrigation. Using such micro-irrigation systems has also been linked to an increase in the yield of crops.

questionText: The lower Gangetic plain is characterised by a humid climate with high temperature throughout the year. Which one among the following pairs of crops is most suitable for this region?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: The low and deltaic plains of the Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers are characterised by humid climate with high temperature throughout the year. Paddy and Jute are the most suitable crops for this region. Paddy is the first-ranking crop in the vast region stretching from lower Gangetic Plain to Brahmaputra Valley in the east and the circum-coastal alluvial tracts of the Peninsula region.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
Wetland/Lake Location
1. Hokera Wetland Punjab
2. Renuka Wetland Himachal Pradesh
3. Rudrasagar Lake Tripura
4. Sasthamkotta Lake Tamil Nadu
How many pairs given above are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation:
Only 2 pairs are correctly matched:
1. Hokera Wetland: Jammu and Kashmir
2. Renuka Wetland: Himachal Pradesh
3. Rudrasagar Lake: Tripura
4. Sasthamkotta Lake: Kerala

questionText: With reference to India, Didwana, Kuchaman, Sargol and Khatu are the names of
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Didwana, Kuchaman, Sargol and Khatu are the names of some of the important saltwater lakes in India. A salt lake or saline lake is a landlocked body of water that has a concentration of salts (typically sodium chloride) and other dissolved minerals significantly higher than most lakes (often defined as at least three grams of salt per litre).

questionText: What is common to the places known as Aliyar, Isapur and Kangsabati?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Aliyar, Isapur and Kangsabati are related to water reservoirs. The Kangsabati Reservoir Project is in West Bengal, Aliyar Reservoir is in Tamil Nadu, and Isapur reservoir is in Maharashtra.

questionText:
Consider the following statements:
1. The Barren Island volcano is an active volcano located in Indian territory.
2. Barren Island lies about 140 km east of Great Nicobar.
3. The last time the Barren Island volcano erupted was in 1991 and it has remained inactive since then.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Statement 1 is correct: Barren Island is an active volcano in the Andaman Islands.\nStatement 2 is incorrect: Barren Island lies about 140 km from Port Blair, not Great Nicobar.\nStatement 3 is incorrect: The last recorded eruption of Barren Island volcano was in 2018, not 1991.

questionText: Which one of the following is an artificial lake?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Kodaikanal Lake in Tamil Nadu is one of the finest man-made (artificial) lakes in India. Kolleru lake in Andhra Pradesh is a natural freshwater lake. Naini Lake in Uttarakhand is a natural lake. Renuka lake in Himachal Pradesh is also a natural lake.

questionText: Among the following cities, which one lies on a longitude closest to that of Delhi?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: The longitude of Delhi is 77.1025° E. Bengaluru with longitude 77.5946° E lies on the longitude closest to that of Delhi. Hyderabad: 78.4867° E, Nagpur: 79.0882° E, Pune: 73.8567° E

questionText: If you travel by road from Kohima to Kottayam, what is the minimum number of States within India through which you can travel, including the origin and the destination?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: The shortest route from Kohima to Kottayam will pass through the minimum seven states: Nagaland-Assam-West Bengal-Odisha-Andhra Pradesh-Tamil Nadu-Kerala.

questionText: At one of the places in India, if you stand on the seashore and watch the sea, you will find that the seawater recedes from the shoreline a few kilometres and comes back to the shore, twice a day, and you can actually walk on the seafloor when the water recedes. This unique phenomenon is seen at
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: The Chandipur beach in the Balasore district of Odisha experiences this unique phenomenon. During low tides, the beach recedes up to 5 KM, allowing visitors to walk on the seabed. This occurs twice a day due to the ebb and flow of tides.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
Place of Pilgrimage Location
1. Srisailam Nallamala Hills
2. Omkareshwar Satmala Hills
3. Pushkar Mahadeo Hills
Which of the above pairs is/are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Pair 1 is correct: Srisailam is located in the Nallamala Hills in Andhra Pradesh.\nPair 2 is incorrect: Omkareshwar is located on an island in the Narmada River, not in Satmala Hills.\nPair 3 is incorrect: Pushkar is located in the Aravalli Range in Rajasthan, not in Mahadeo Hills.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
1. Dampa Tiger Reserve : Mizoram
2. Gumti Wildlife Sanctuary : Sikkim
3. Saramati Peak : Nagaland
Which of the above pairs is/are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Pair 1 is correct: The Dampa Tiger Reserve is the largest wildlife sanctuary in Mizoram.\nPair 2 is incorrect: The Gumti Wildlife Sanctuary is located in Tripura, not Sikkim.\nPair 3 is correct: Saramati is the highest peak (3841m) in Nagaland, located on the Nagaland-Myanmar border.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
National Highway Cities connected
1. NH 4 Chennai and Hyderabad
2. NH 6 Mumbai and Kolkata
3. NH 15 Ahmedabad and Jodhpur
Which of the above pairs is/are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: None of the pairs are correctly matched. NH 4 connects Mumbai and Chennai via Bangalore. NH 6 connects Kolkata and Surat via Raipur. NH 15 connects Samakhiali (Gujarat) to Pathankot (Punjab) via Rajasthan (Jodhpur).

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
National Park River flowing through the park
1. Corbett National Park : Ganga
2. Kaziranga National Park : Manas
3. Silent Valley National Park : Kaveri
Which of the above pairs is/are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: None of the pairs are correctly matched. Corbett National Park: Ramganga River. Kaziranga National Park: Brahmaputra River. Silent Valley National Park: Kunthipuzha River.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
1. Nokrek Biosphere Reserve : Garo Hills
2. Logtak (Loktak) Lake : Barail Range
3. Namdapha National Park : Dafla Hills
Which of the above pairs is/are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Pair 1 is correct: Nokrek Biosphere Reserve is located in the Garo Hills of Meghalaya.\nPair 2 is incorrect: Loktak Lake is in Manipur, not in the Barail Range.\nPair 3 is incorrect: Namdapha National Park is in Arunachal Pradesh, not in the Dafla Hills.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
Tribe State
1. Limboo (Limbu) : Sikkim
2. Karbi : Himachal Pradesh
3. Dongaria Kondh : Odisha
4. Bonda : Tamil Nadu
Which of the above pairs are correctly matched?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation:
Pair 1 is correct: Limboo tribe is found in Sikkim.
Pair 2 is incorrect: Karbi tribe is found in Assam, not Himachal Pradesh.
Pair 3 is correct: Dongaria Kondh tribe is found in Odisha.
Pair 4 is incorrect: Bonda tribe is found in Odisha, not Tamil Nadu.

questionText:
A particular State in India has the following characteristics:
1. It is located on the same latitude which passes through northern Rajasthan.
2. It has over 80% of its area under forest cover.
3. Over 12% of forest cover constitutes the Protected Area Network in this State.
Which one among the following States has all the above characteristics?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation:
Arunachal Pradesh fits all the characteristics:
1. It lies between 26° 28'N - 29° 30'N, which passes through northern Rajasthan.
2. It has over 80% forest cover (80.50% as per India State of Forest Report 2011).
3. It has a large network of protected areas covering 18.48% of recorded forest area.

questionText:
With reference to 'Changpa' community of India, consider the following statements:
1. They live mainly in the State of Uttarakhand.
2. They rear the Pashmina goats that yield fine wool.
3. They are kept in the category of Scheduled Tribes.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect: The Changpa live in Ladakh, not Uttarakhand.\nStatement 2 is correct: They rear Pashmina goats that yield fine wool.\nStatement 3 is correct: They are categorized as a Scheduled Tribe.

questionText: Which one of the following pairs of islands is separated from each other by the 'Ten Degree Channel'?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation: The Ten Degree Channel separates the Andaman Islands from the Nicobar Islands. It is a channel in the southeastern part of the Bay of Bengal. It is approximately 150 km wide and lies on the 10-degree line of latitude, north of the equator.

questionText:
Consider the following towns of India:
1. Bhadrachalam
2. Chanderi
3. Kancheepuram
4. Karnal
Which of the above are famous for the production of traditional sarees/fabric?
subject: Indian Geography
explanation:
Chanderi in Madhya Pradesh is famous for its hand-woven sarees.
Kancheepuram in Tamil Nadu is renowned for its hand-woven silk sarees.
Bhadrachalam is famous for its Lord Ram temple, not for sarees.
Karnal is known for its shoe industry, not for traditional textiles.

questionText:
With reference to India's Desert National Park, which of the following statements are correct?
1. It is spread over two districts.
2. There is no human habitation inside the Park.
3. It is one of the natural habitats of the Great Indian Bustard.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Desert National Park is situated in the Indian state of Rajasthan. It covers an area of 3162 km² of which 1900 km² is in Jaisalmer district and the remaining 1262 km² is in Barmer district of Rajasthan State.

Statement 2 is not correct: There are 73 villages and settlements or Dhanis existing within the Park. These communities have inhabited this area for hundreds of years.

Statement 3 is correct: The DNP is one of the natural habitats of the Great Indian Bustard.

questionText:
Which of the following are the most likely places to find the musk deer in its natural habitat?
1. Askot Wildlife Sanctuary
2. Gangotri National Park
3. Kishanpur Wildlife Sanctuary
4. Manas National Park
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation: The musk deer is most likely found in Askot Wildlife Sanctuary (also known as Askot Musk Deer Sanctuary), located in the Pithoragarh district of Kumaun, Uttarakhand and the Gangotri Wildlife National Park in Uttarkashi District of Uttarakhand in India.

questionText: Which one of the following protected areas is well-known for the conservation of a sub-species of the Indian swamp deer (Barasingha) that thrives well on hard ground and is exclusively graminivorous?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation: Hard ground swamp deer (Barasingha or Rucervus duvaucelii), the state animal of Madhya Pradesh, is seeing a revival in the Kanha National Park and Tiger Reserve (KNPTR) after having been perilously close to extinction for a long time. KNPTR is on the Maikal range of the Satpura hills and is spread over an area of 940 square kilometers between the Mandla and Balaghat districts of Madhya Pradesh. The swamp deer is endemic to KNPTR.

questionText: Among the following Tiger Reserves, which one has the largest area under "Critical Tiger Habitat"?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation: Nagarjunsagar-Srisailam Tiger Reserve is the largest tiger reserve in India. The reserve spreads over five districts, Kurnool District, Prakasam District, Guntur District, Nalgonda District and Mahbubnagar district. The total area of the tiger reserve is 3,728 km2 (1,439 sq mi).

questionText: In which one of the following States is Pakhui Wildlife Sanctuary located?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation: Pakhui Wildlife Sanctuary lies in the foothills of the Eastern Himalaya, in the East Kameng District of Arunachal Pradesh. It was declared a Tiger Reserve in 2002. The habitat comprises lowland semi-evergreen, evergreen, and Eastern Himalayan broadleaf forests.

questionText: Which one of the following National Parks has a climate that varies from tropical to subtropical, temperate, and arctic?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation: Namdapha National Park is located in Arunachal Pradesh. It was declared as a tiger reserve under Project Tiger. The main vegetation of Namdapha is evergreen forests, moist deciduous forests, subtropical forests, temperate forests and alpine. It has a climate that varies from tropical to subtropical, temperate, and arctic.

questionText: Which of the following National Parks is unique in being a swamp with floating vegetation that supports a rich biodiversity?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation: Keibul Lamjao National Park is the only floating park in the world. The Park is located in the southwestern part of Loktak Lake. The Loktak Lake has a unique ecosystem called 'Phumdi' (a Manipuri word meaning floating mats of soil and vegetation).

questionText: Which one of the following is used in preparing a natural mosquito repellent?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Lemongrass acts as a natural mosquito repellent. It helps one to get rid of mosquitoes and keep them at bay. All you need to do is crush the leaves of lemongrass and then apply the oily mixture to your skin.

questionText:
Consider the following pairs:
Wetlands Conference of rivers
1. Harike Wetlands: Confluence of Beas and Satluj/ Sutlej
2. Keoladeo Ghana National Park: Confluence of Banas and Chambal
3. Kolleru Lake: Confluence of Musi and Krishna
Which of the above pairs is/are correctly matched?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation:
Pair 1 is correctly matched: Harike Wetlands is one of the largest man-made wetlands of northern India. It came into existence in 1952 after the construction of a barrage near the confluence of rivers Sutlej and Beas.

Pair 2 is not correctly matched: Keoladeo Ghana National Park is formed by the confluence of the Gambira and Banganga rivers.

Pair 3 is not correctly matched: Kolleru Lake is the confluence of Godavari and Krishna.

questionText:
Consider the following protected areas;
1. Bandipur
2. Bhitarkanika
3. Manas
4. Sunderbans
Which of the above are declared Tiger Reserves?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
topic: Protected Area Network: NP, WS, BR, etc.
explanation:
Out of the given protected areas, Bandipur, Manas, and Sunderbans are declared as Tiger Reserves, but Bhitarkanika is not.
Bandipur: Located in Karnataka, Bandipur National Park is part of the Niligiri Biosphere Reserve and has been designated as a Tiger Reserve under Project Tiger, making it an important habitat for Bengal tigers.
Manas: Situated in Assam, Manas National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and also a designated Tiger Reserve. It is known for its diverse wildlife, including tigers, elephants, and the golden langur.
Sunderbans: Located in West Bengal, the Sunderbans Tiger Reserve is part of the Sunderbans Delta and is famous for its population of Royal Bengal Tigers. The mangrove ecosystem makes it unique among tiger habitats.
Bhitarkanika: Situated in Odisha, Bhitarkanika National Park is known for its mangrove forests, saltwater crocodiles, and rich biodiversity, but it is not a designated Tiger Reserve. It is primarily known for its crocodile conservation efforts.
Thus, Bhitarkanika is not a Tiger Reserve, and the correct protected areas that are declared Tiger Reserves are Bandipur, Manas, and Sunderbans.

questionText: Certain species of which one of the following organisms are well known as cultivators of fungi?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Attine ants, a group of over 200 ant species, are known to cultivate fungi. They use various agricultural techniques to raise mutualistic fungi in fungus gardens. The more primitive species cultivate fungi on organic detritus, while advanced leaf-cutting genera like Atta and Acromyrmex harvest vegetation and process it into pulp to feed the fungi they raise.

questionText: The "Miyawaki method" is well known for the :
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The Miyawaki method involves planting two to four trees per square meter. Miyawaki forests grow in two to three years and are self-sustaining. They help lower temperatures in concrete heat islands, reduce air and noise pollution, attract local birds and insects, and create carbon sinks.

options.text: Promotion of commercial farming in arid and semi-arid areas
Development of gardens using genetically modified flora
Creation of mini forests in urban areas
Harvesting wind energy on coastal areas and on sea surfaces

questionText:
The average score of a batsman after his 50th innings was 46.4.
After 60th innings, his average Score increases by 2.6.
What was his average score in the last ten innings?
subject: Quantitative ability

questionText:
Which of the following are nitrogen-fixing plants?
1. Alfalfa
2. Amaranth
3. Chickpea
4. Clover
5. Purslane (Kulfa)
6. Spinach
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Rhizobium is a nitrogen-fixing bacteria that lives symbiotically within the roots of several leguminous plants such as alfalfa, sweet clover, sweet pea, lentils, etc. Alfalfa, chickpea (a pulse crop), and clover are leguminous plants that can fix nitrogen. Amaranth, purslane, and spinach are not nitrogen-fixing plants.

questionText: "If rainforests and tropical forests are the lungs of the Earth, then surely wetlands function as its kidneys." Which one of the following functions of wetlands best reflects the above statement ?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Heavy metals in aquatic environments have been extensively studied due to their toxicity, persistence, and tendency to bioaccumulate. Many studies have shown that aquatic plants act as sinks for heavy metals in aquatic ecosystems. Several species of aquatic macrophytes like H. verticillata and water hyacinth have been used to remove heavy metals from wastewater due to their capacity to accumulate these metals.

options.text: The water cycle in wetlands involves surface runoff, subsoil percolation and evaporation.
Algae form the nutrient base upon which fish, crustaceans, molluscs, birds, reptiles and mammals thrive.
Wetlands play a vital role in maintaining sedimentation balance and soil stabilization.
Aquatic plants absorb heavy metals and excess nutrients.

questionText: What is blue carbon?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Blue carbon refers to carbon captured by ocean and coastal ecosystems around the world. Through sequestration, oceans and coasts provide a natural means to reduce the influence of greenhouse gases on our atmosphere. Seagrasses, mangroves, and salt marshes along our coast operate as carbon sinks, capturing and storing carbon.

options.text: Carbon captured by oceans and coastal ecosystems
Carbon sequestered in forest biomass and agricultural soils
Carbon contained in petroleum and natural gas

questionText: In case of which one of the following biogeochemical cycles, the weathering of rocks is the main source of release of nutrients to enter the cycle?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The phosphorus cycle is the process by which phosphorus moves through the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere. Much of the phosphorus on Earth is tied up in rock and sedimentary deposits, from which it is released by weathering, leaching, and mining. The carbon cycle and nitrogen cycle are gaseous cycles and are not primarily related to the weathering of rocks.

questionText:
Consider the following kinds of organisms :
1. Copepods
2. Cyanobacteria
3. Diatoms
4. Foraminifera
Which of the above are primary producers in the food chains of oceans?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Primary producers in marine ecosystems include bacteria, phytoplankton, and algae. Cyanobacteria (also called blue-green algae) are essential primary producers in aquatic environments. Diatoms are one of the ocean's most important primary producers. Copepods are important secondary producers in the oceans. Foraminifera are single-celled organisms and are not primary producers.

questionText:
In the nature, which of the following is/are most likely to be found surviving on a surface without soil?
1. Fern
2. Lichen
3. Moss
4. Mushroom
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Lichens can grow on practically any surface and can grow from sea level to high alpine heights under various climatic situations. Mosses are non-vascular plants that lack xylem and phloem for transporting water. They have rhizoids that anchor them and take in water, allowing them to grow low and flat along surfaces without soil. Ferns need indirect sunlight, moist soil, and a humid environment to thrive. Mushrooms are the fruiting bodies of fungi that typically grow on soil or their food source.

questionText:
Which of the following are detritivores?
1. Earthworms
2. Jellyfish
3. Millipedes
4. Seahorses
5. Woodlice
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
A detritivore is a heterotrophic organism that obtains its nutrition by feeding on detritus. Detritivores and decomposers contribute to the breakdown of all of the dead and decaying material in any ecosystem. Some examples of detritivores are:
- Earthworms
- Millipedes
- Woodlice
Seahorses are carnivores. Jellyfish are carnivores and can increase in size rapidly and procreate in large numbers when food is abundant.

questionText:
Which of the following have species that can establish a symbiotic relationship with other organisms?
1. Cnidarians
2. Fungi
3. Protozoa
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
A symbiosis is an evolved interaction or close living relationship between organisms from different species, usually with benefits to one or both of the individuals involved. Some symbiotic relations are:
- The link between cnidarians and dinoflagellate algae.
- Mycorrhiza and lichen
- Symbiosis in protozoa mostly represents a close mutualistic association between a protozoan and unicellular symbionts (bacteria, cyanobacteria or/and unicellular algae) or protozoans and a multicellular organism (ruminants, lower termites, wood-eating cockroaches, plants).

questionText:
Consider the following animals:
1. Hedgehog
2. Marmot
3. Pangolin
To reduce the chance of being captured by predators, which of the above organisms rolls up/roll up and protects/ protect its/their vulnerable parts?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Hedgehogs have spines which are known as quills, and they know how to use them. When they feel threatened, their quills immediately go up in full force. To protect himself, a hedgehog coils his head and feet into his body and creates a ball.\nWhen threatened, a pangolin will curl up into a tight ball and defend itself with its sharp-scaled tails.\nWhen the yellow-bellied marmot sees a predator, it whistles to alert the others in the area, then hides under a nearby rock pile until the threat has passed. They do not roll up.

questionText:
The vegetation of savannah consists of grassland with scattered small trees, but extensive areas have no trees. The forest development in such areas is generally kept in check by one or more or a combination of some conditions. Which of the following are such conditions?
1. Burrowing animals and termites
2. Fire
3. Grazing herbivores
4. Seasonal rainfall
5. Soil properties
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The Savanna or Sudan Climate is a transitional type of climate found between the equatorial forests and the trade wind hot deserts. The forest development in savannah areas is generally kept in check by Fire, Grazing herbivores, and Seasonal rainfall. This climate is characterized by an alternate hot, rainy season and cool, dry season. The annual rainfall is not sufficient and scattered over the year, which is not enough to develop forests. There are two main groups of animals in the savanna, the grass-eating herbivorous animals and the fleshing-eating carnivorous animals. The herbivorous animals check the growth of forests. The tall brown bushes are burnt down by the farmers in preparation for new fields for the following year. Sometimes fires may be caused by the dry, dusty Harmattan. They also check the growth of forests.

questionText: "Leaf litter decomposes faster than in any other biome and as a result the soil surface is often almost bare. Apart from trees, the vegetation is largely composed of plant forms that reach up into the canopy vicariously, by climbing the trees or growing as epiphytes, rooted on the upper branches of trees." This is the most likely description of
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Tropical rainforests are luxuriant forests found in wet tropical lands around the Equator. In tropical rainforests, leaf litter decomposes faster than in any other biome, and as a result, the soil surface is often almost bare. Apart from trees, the vegetation is largely composed of plant forms that reach up into the canopy vicariously by climbing the trees or growing as epiphytes, rooted on the upper branches of trees. The tropical rainforest is a hot, moist biome where it rains all year long. The bottom layer or floor of the rainforest is covered with wet leaves and leaf litter. This material decomposes rapidly in wet, warm conditions (like a compost pile), sending nutrients back into the soil. Few plants are found on the floor of the forest due to the lack of sunlight.

questionText: Why is a plant called Prosopis juliflora often mentioned in the news?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Prosopis juliflora (vilayati kikar or vilayati babul), an exotic tree, is one of the top invaders in India. It was introduced into India from South America and has become naturalised all-over north India. This tree is also affecting the nesting success of birds. It tends to reduce the biodiversity in the area in which it grows. Invasive plants are those plants which spread to regions other than their native and thrive to the extent of becoming a threat to local species. Alien invasive species occur in all groups of plants and animals. They include competitors, predators, pathogens, and parasites. They have invaded almost every type of native ecosystem and have caused hundreds of extinctions.

options.text: Its extract is widely used in cosmetics.
It tends to reduce the biodiversity in the area in which it grows.
Its extract is used in the synthesis of pesticides.

questionText:
Which of the following leaf modifications occur(s) in desert areas to inhibit water loss?
1. Hard and waxy leaves
2. Tiny leaves
3. Thorns instead of leaves
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Desert plants lose very little water through transpiration. The leaves in desert plants are either absent, very small (tiny), or they are present in the shape of spines. This helps in reducing the loss of water from the leaves through transpiration plants growing in extremely dry conditions throughout the year adopt thorns instead of leaves to prevent loss of water. Photosynthesis in these plants is usually carried out by the stems. The stem is also covered with a thick waxy layer, which helps to retain water. Hence, they have hard and waxy leaves as well. Most desert plants have roots that go very deep into the soil for absorbing water. Xerophytes are plants growing in extremely dry conditions throughout the year. For example, plants growing in deserts (psammophytes), on rock (lithophytes), or alpine plants growing above 14000 feet altitude.

questionText:
Due to some reasons, if there is a huge fall in the population of species of butterflies, what could be its likely consequence/consequences?
1. Pollination of some plants could be adversely affected.
2. There could be a drastic increase in the fungal infections of some cultivated plants.
3. It could lead to a fall in the population of some species of wasps, spiders, and birds.
Select the correct one using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Butterflies are crucial pollinators, and their contribution to global agriculture is valued only next to honeybees. Butterflies probe for nectar, their flight fuel, and typically favour the flat, clustered flowers that provide a landing pad and abundant rewards. No such concrete evidence is found that ensures a drastic increase in the fungal infections of some cultivated plants. The leaf-feeding activity of leaf beetles (Not Butterflies) may increase the plant's susceptibility to bacterial or fungal infections. A fall in their population would also lead to a fall in their predator population like the wasps, spiders, and birds. A butterfly needs two types of plants: Nectar plants for adults and larval host plants for caterpillars.

questionText: Which one of the following is the best description of the term 'ecosystem'?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: An ecosystem can be visualised as a functional unit of nature, where living organisms interact among themselves and with the surrounding physical environment. Ecosystem varies greatly in size from a small pond to a large forest or a sea. The interaction of biotic and abiotic components results in a physical structure that is characteristic of each type of ecosystem. The components of the ecosystem are seen to function as a unit when we consider the aspects of Productivity, Decomposition, Energy flow, and Nutrient cycling. Thus, an ecosystem is a community of organisms together with the environment in which they live.

options.text: A community of organisms interacting with one another
That part of the Earth that is inhabited by living organisms
A community of organisms together with the environment in which they live
The flora and fauna of a geographical area

questionText: Which one of the following regions of India has a combination of mangrove forest, evergreen forest, and deciduous forest?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
The vegetation of Andaman and Nicobar Islands may be broadly classified into beach forests, mangrove forests, wet evergreen forests, semi-evergreen forests, moist deciduous forests, and grasslands. Additional Information:
- Indira Point, the southernmost point of India is the southern point of Great Nicobar Island.
- Andaman and Nicobar Islands are separated by a water body which is called the Ten-degree channel.
- Barren Island, the only active volcano in India is also situated in the Nicobar Islands.
- The coastal line has some coral deposits and beautiful beaches. These islands receive convectional rainfall and have an equatorial type of vegetation.
- Some important mountain peaks in Andaman and Nicobar Islands are Saddle peak, Mount Diavolo, Mount Koyob, and Mount Thuillier.

questionText:
Which of the following adds/add carbon dioxide to the carbon cycle on the planet Earth?
1. Volcanic action
2. Respiration
3. Photosynthesis
4. Decay of organic matter
 Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Photosynthesis absorbs carbon dioxide and releases oxygen, meaning it does not contribute carbon dioxide to the carbon cycle. Therefore, statement 3 is incorrect.
Volcanic activity releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
Respiration involves transporting oxygen from the external environment into cells within tissues and releasing carbon dioxide in the opposite direction.
The decomposition process also releases carbon dioxide.

questionText: Among the following organisms, which one does not belong to the class of the other three?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: A Mite, Spider and Scorpion belong to the category of Arachnids, while Crabs belong to the category of crustaceans.

questionText: Which one of the following is the process involved in photosynthesis?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: During the process of photosynthesis in plants, the free energy of light is harvested by photosynthetic pigments which is chlorophyll in the chloroplast. This free energy of light is trapped and used in the synthesis of chemical energy in molecules ATP and NADPH. This energy generated is used in fixing CO and for carbohydrates, which is glucose and stored for future use.

options.text: Potential energy is released to form free energy.
Free energy is converted into potential energy and stored.
Food is oxidised to release carbon dioxide and water.
Oxygen is taken, and carbon dioxide and water vapour are given out.

questionText:
With reference to the food chains in ecosystems, which of the following kinds of organism is/are known as decomposer organism/organisms?
1. Virus
2. Fungi
3. Bacteria
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Fungi and bacteria are known decomposers. They break down complex organic matter into inorganic substances like carbon dioxide, water, and nutrients through the process of decomposition. Viruses are not considered decomposers as they need a living host organism and are more like parasites.

questionText: In the grasslands, trees do not replace the grasses as a part of an ecological succession because of
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: In the grasslands, trees do not replace the grasses as a part of an ecological succession because of water limits and fire. Grassland vegetation grows in areas of moderate to low amounts of rainfall. This scarcity of water limits the growth of grasses and also the conversion of grasslands into forests.

options.text: limited sunlight and paucity of nutrients

questionText: Which one of the following is the correct sequence of ecosystems in the order of decreasing productivity?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The correct sequence of ecosystems in the order of decreasing productivity is Mangroves, grasslands, lakes, and oceans. Net ecosystem production (NEP) is defined as the difference between gross primary production and total ecosystem respiration, representing the total amount of organic carbon in an ecosystem available for storage, export as organic carbon, or non-biological oxidation to carbon dioxide through fire or ultraviolet oxidation.

questionText:
Due to improper/indiscriminate disposal of old and used computers or their parts, which of the following are released into the environment as e-waste?
1. Beryllium
2. Cadmium
3. Chromium
4. Heptachlor
5. Mercury
6. Lead
7. Plutonium
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Electronic waste (e-waste) typically includes discarded computer monitors, motherboards, mobile phones and chargers, compact discs, headphones, television sets, air conditioners, and refrigerators. The improper disposal of these items can release harmful substances into the environment, including beryllium, cadmium, chromium, mercury, and lead.

questionText: Acid rain is caused by the pollution of environment by
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Acid rain is caused by the pollution of the environment by nitrous oxide and sulphur dioxide. These oxides, which are acidic in nature, can be blown by the wind along with solid particles in the atmosphere and finally settle down either on the ground as dry deposition or in water, fog and snow as wet deposition. The burning of fossil fuels (which contain sulphur and nitrogenous matter) such as coal and oil in power stations and furnaces or petrol and diesel in motor engines produces sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxides.

questionText:
With reference to food chains in ecosystems, consider the following statements:
1. A food chain illustrates the order in which a chain of organisms feeds upon each other.
2. Food chains are found within the populations of a species.
3. A food chain illustrates the numbers of each organism that are eaten by others.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Statement 1 is correct: A food chain illustrates the order in which a chain of organisms feeds upon each other. Statement 2 is incorrect: Food chains are not found within populations of a species  they involve different species. Statement 3 is incorrect: A food chain does not illustrate the numbers of each organism eaten by others  it simply shows the feeding relationships.

questionText:
Which of the following adds/add nitrogen to the soil?
1. Excretion of urea by animals
2. Burning of coal by man
3. Death of vegetation
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Excretion of urea by animals adds nitrogen to the soil, as urea is the main nitrogen-containing substance in the urine of mammals and is widely used in fertilizers as a convenient source of nitrogen. The death of vegetation adds to soil organic matter, including humus. As organic matter decomposes, inorganic nitrogen is released into the soil. Burning coal does not produce nitrogen or its compounds.

questionText:
With reference to food chains in ecosystems, consider the following statements:
1. A food chain illustrates the order in which a chain of organisms feeds upon each other.
2. Food chains are found within the populations of a species.
3. A food chain illustrates the numbers of each organism that are eaten by others.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Organisms in the ecosystem are related to each other through feeding mechanisms or trophic levels, i.e., one organism becomes food for the other. A sequence of organisms that feed on one another, form a food chain. A food chain starts with producers and ends with top carnivores.

Statement 2 is not correct: A food chain represents only one part of the food or energy flow through an ecosystem and implies a simple, isolated relationship, which seldom occurs in ecosystems. Food chains are not found within the populations of a species (dogs would not eat dogs).

Statement 3 is not correct: A food web illustrates all possible transfers of energy and nutrients among the organisms in an ecosystem, whereas a food chain traces only one pathway of the food.

questionText:
Which of the following adds/add nitrogen to the soil?
1. Excretion of urea by animals
2. Burning of coal by man
3. Death of vegetation
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Excretion of urea by animals adds nitrogen to the soil, as urea is the main nitrogen-containing substance in the urine of mammals, therefore urea is widely used in fertilizers as the convenient source of nitrogen. Burning coal does not produce Nitrogen or its compounds. Death of vegetation adds up in soil organic matter including humus. As organic matter decomposes inorganic nitrogen is released into the soil.

questionText: Which one of the following terms describes not only the physical space occupied by an organism but also its functional role in the community of organisms?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Each organism has an invariably defined range of conditions that it can tolerate, diversity in the resources it utilizes, and a distinct functional role in the ecological system, all these together comprise its niche (Ecological niche). The term niche means the sum of all the activities and relationships of a species by which it uses the resources in its habitat for its survival and reproduction.

questionText:
Consider the following kinds of organisms:
1. Bat
2. Bee
3. Bird
Which of the above is/are pollinating agent/agents?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Pollination is the act of transferring pollen grains from the male anther of a flower to the female stigma. The process results in fertilisation which produces seeds and, in some cases, fruits. Pollinators are Bees, Flies, Beetles, Birds, bats, butterflies, moths, wasps, and small mammals. They place themselves on flowers to drink nectar or feed off of pollen and ferry pollen grains as they shift from one place to another.

questionText: The Millennium Ecosystem Assessment describes the following major categories of ecosystem services-provisioning, supporting, regulating, preserving and cultural. Which one of the following is supporting service?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The category of support services is an important distinction to make when discussing the ecosystem services provided by a natural area. The Millennium Ecosystem Assessment has defined four broad categories of ecosystem services. These are: supporting, regulating, provisioning and cultural services. The supporting services which are necessary for the production of all other ecosystem services are food, nutrient cycling and primary production.

questionText:
What would happen if phytoplankton of an ocean is completely destroyed for some reason?
1. The ocean as a carbon sink would be adversely affected.
2. The food chains in the ocean would be adversely affected.
3. The density of ocean water would drastically decrease.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Like land plants, phytoplankton have chlorophyll to capture sunlight, and they use photosynthesis to turn it into chemical energy. They consume carbon dioxide and release oxygen. All phytoplankton photosynthesize, but some get additional energy by consuming other organisms. Therefore, if the phytoplankton of an ocean is completely destroyed for some reason, then the ocean as a carbon sink would be adversely affected.

Statement 2 is correct: Phytoplankton forms the basis of the marine food chain and sustains diverse assemblages of species ranging from tiny zooplankton to large marine mammals, seabirds, and fish. "Phytoplankton is the fuel on which marine ecosystems run. A decline of phytoplankton affects everything up the food chain, including humans.

Statement 3 is not correct: Density of ocean water at the sea surface is about 1027 kg/m 3. There are two main factors that make ocean water more or less dense than about 1027 kg/m 3: the temperature of the water and the salinity of the water. Ocean water gets denser as temperature goes down and vice versa.

questionText:
In the context of ecosystem productivity, marine upwelling zones are important as they increase marine productivity by bringing the:
1. Decomposer microorganisms to the surface
2. Nutrients to the surface
3. Bottom-dwelling organisms to the surface
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Statement 1 and statement 3 are not correct: Microorganisms are natural decomposers as they possess an enormous ability to utilise diverse types of organic substances as a source of energy and convert toxic ones into harmless by-products. They do not have any relevance in the context of ecosystem productivity. Organisms and decomposer microorganisms would remain where they are, no movement to the surface can be noticed at the upwelling zone.\n\nStatement 2 is correct: Upwelling is an oceanographic phenomenon that involves the wind-driven motion of dense, cooler, and usually, nutrient-rich water towards the ocean surface, replacing the warmer, usually nutrient-depleted surface water. The increased availability in upwelling regions results in high levels of primary productivity and thus fishery production. Approximately 25% of the total global marine fish catches come from five upwellings that occupy only 5% of the total ocean area.

questionText: If a tropical rainforest is removed, it does not regenerate quickly as compared to a tropical deciduous forest. This is because
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The soil of the rainforest is deficient in nutrients. Here rainforest means Rainfall throughout the year. It rains almost every day during this the topsoil is continuously washed away which may result in nutrients being washed away. It will start leaching of nutrients and very little fertility remains in the topsoil. In this case, most of the seeds don't germinate for years. The Regeneration Process will be very slow (it may take decades). But the layer below topsoil (subsoil) is very fertile. So, plants grow very quickly once their roots reach the sub-soil and if they receive enough sunlight.

options.text: The soil of the rainforest is deficient in nutrients.
Propagules of the trees in a rainforest have poor viability.
The rain forest species are slow growing.
Exotic species invade the fertile soil of the rainforest.

questionText:
Consider the following:
1. Carbon monoxide
2. Nitrogen oxide
3. Ozone
4. Sulphur dioxide
Excess of which of the above in the environment is/are cause(s) of acid rain?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Acid rain, or acid deposition, is a broad term that includes any form of precipitation with acidic components, such as sulfuric or nitric acid that fall to the ground from the atmosphere in wet or dry forms. This can include rain, snow, fog, hail or even dust that is acidic.\n\nAcid rain results when sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOX) are emitted into the atmosphere and transported by wind and air currents. The SO2 and NOX react with water, oxygen and other chemicals to form sulfuric and nitric acids. These then mix with water and other materials before falling to the ground.

questionText: Among the following crops, which one is the most important anthropogenic source of both methane and nitrous oxide?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Rice cultivation has been identified as one of the important sources of GHGs, namely methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O).

According to a global analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) in the US, methane and nitrous oxide emissions from rice farms could have the same long-term warming impact as about 600 coal plants.

The researchers investigated greenhouse gas emissions from rice farms across southern India. They found that nitrous oxide emissions from rice can contribute up to 99% of the total climate impact of rice cultivation at a variety of intermittently flooded farms.

questionText:
With reference to polyethylene terephthalate, the use of which is so widespread in our daily lives, consider the following statements:
1. Its fibres can be blended with wool and cotton fibres to reinforce their properties.
2. Containers made of it can be used to store any alcoholic beverage.
3. Bottles made of it can be recycled into other products.
4. Articles made of it can be easily disposed of by incineration without causing greenhouse gas emissions.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Polyethylene terephthalate is a polymer created by the combination of two monomers: modified ethylene glycol and purified terephthalic acid. Its fibers can be blended with wool and cotton fibers to reinforce their properties.

Statement 2 is not correct: PET Containers are widespread in our lives But it is not recommended for storage of any alcoholic beverage.

Statement 3 is correct: Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) is a highly recyclable plastic resin and a form of polyester.

Statement 4 is not correct: Emission of greenhouse gases is one of the major disadvantages associated with the disposal of PET by incineration process.

Elimination Technique: Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET or PETE) is plastic, so while incinerating the PET it will emit greenhouse gasses.

questionText:
In the context of WHO Air Quality Guidelines, consider the following statements:
1. The 24-hour mean of PM2.5 should not exceed 15 μg/m3 and annual mean of PM2.5 should not exceed 5μg/m3.
2. In a year, the highest levels of ozone pollution occur during the periods of inclement weather.
3. PM10 can penetrate the lung barrier and enter the bloodstream.
4. Excessive ozone in the air can trigger asthma.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: WHO's new guidelines recommend air quality levels for six pollutants — particulate matter (PM), ozone (O₃), nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) sulfur dioxide (SO₂), and carbon monoxide (CO) — that are not just health hazards but they also give rise to other damaging pollutants. The recommendation for PM 2.5 is that the annual average should not exceed 5 micrograms per cubic meter or 15 micrograms per cubic meter in a day.

Statement 2 is not correct: Ozone levels are typically highest during the afternoon hours of the summer months when the influence of direct sunlight is the greatest. Inclement weather is unpleasant, especially with cold wind and rain. So, Ozone pollution will be low during inclement weather.

Statement 3 is not correct: Particulate matter 2.5 (PM2.5) (not PM10) are such small particles that can penetrate the human lung barrier and enter the blood system.

Statement 4 is correct: Excessive Ozone like other air pollutants in the air can trigger asthma.

questionText:
Magnetite particles, suspected to cause neurodegenerative problems, are generated as environmental pollutants from which of the following?
1. Brakes of motor vehicles
2. Engines of motor vehicles
3. Microwave stoves within homes
4. Power plants
5. Telephone lines
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Magnetite particles suspected to cause neurodegenerative problems are generated from the following:
- Brakes of motor vehicles
- Engines of motor vehicles
- Power plants

Other sources of magnetite nanoparticles include open fires and poorly sealed stoves within homes.

Currently, there is no study to suggest that they are produced by Microwave stoves within homes and Telephone lines.

questionText:
Why is there a concern about copper smelting plants?
1. They may release lethal quantities of carbon monoxide into the environment.
2. The copper slag can cause the leaching of some heavy metals into the environment.
3. They may release sulphur dioxide as a pollutant.
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Copper smelting plants separate elemental copper from copper concentrates through multiple sulphide oxidizing stages.

Option (b) is correct: The copper slag can cause the leaching of some heavy metals into the environment. Organic vapours and sulfur oxides resulting from secondary smelting roasting operations and fuel combustion can cause smog, containing ozone, fine airborne particles, nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide and carbon monoxide. So, it may release sulphur dioxide as a pollutant.

Copper smelters use carbon monoxide as a reducing agent for copper oxide. Carbon monoxide is not an end product of the reaction. Hence, it is unlikely that a smelter will discharge dangerous levels of carbon monoxide into the atmosphere.

CuO + CO → Cu + CO2.

questionText:
With reference to furnace oil, consider the following statements:
1. It is a product of oil refineries.
2. Some industries use it to generate power.
3. Its use causes sulphur emissions into the environment.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Furnace oil, commonly known as fuel oil, is a viscous black residual fuel predominantly composed of heavy components from the crude distillation unit, short residue, and clarified oil from the fluidized catalytic cracker unit.

Statement 2 is correct: Furnace oil is commonly used in Steam boilers which in turn are used in power plants, ships, and industrial operations.

Statement 3 is correct: Using furnace oil contributes to high sulphur dioxide (SO2) emission and secondary sulphate formation as particulate matter (PM).

questionText:
Consider the following statements:
1. Coal ash contains arsenic, lead and mercury.
2. Coal-fired power plants release sulphur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen into the environment.
3. High ash content is observed in Indian coal.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Coal ash, also referred to as coal combustion residuals or CCRs, is produced primarily from the burning of coal in coal-fired power plants. Coal ash includes several by-products produced from burning coal, including Fly Ash, a very fine, powdery material composed mostly of silica made from the burning of finely ground coal in a boiler; Bottom Ash, a coarse, angular ash particle that is too large to be carried up into the smoke stacks, so it forms in the bottom of the coal furnace; Boiler Slag, molten bottom ash from slag taps and cyclone type furnaces that turn into pellets that have a smooth glassy appearance after it is cooled with water; Flue Gas Desulfurization Material, a material leftover from the process of reducing sulphur dioxide emissions from a coal-fired boiler that can be a wet sludge consisting of calcium sulphite or calcium sulphate or dry powdered material that is a mixture of sulphites and sulphates.

Statement 1 is correct: Coal ash commonly contains some of the earth's deadliest toxics: arsenic, lead, mercury, cadmium, chromium, and selenium.

Statement 2 is correct: Thermal power plants produce large amounts of nitrogen oxides and sulphur dioxide—the pollutants that cause acid rain—when they burn fossil fuels, especially coal, to produce energy.

Statement 3 is correct: India's domestic coal reserves have a high ash content—up to 40 to 45 percent. As a result, more coal is required to generate one-kilowatt hour of electricity. This in turn means higher emissions. Reducing the ash content will mean lower amounts of coal will be burnt for every unit of electricity generated, and that would mean lower emissions of pollutants. Coal washing is one possible way to tackle the problem of high ash content in coal.

questionText:
Which of the following are the reasons/factors for exposure to benzene pollution?
1. Automobile exhaust
2. Tobacco smoke
3. Wood burning
4. Using varnished wooden furniture
5. Using products made of polyurethane
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Human exposure to benzene has been associated with a range of acute and long-term adverse health effects and diseases, including cancer and aplastic anemia. Exposure can occur occupationally and domestically as a result of the ubiquitous use of benzene-containing petroleum products, including motor fuels and solvents. Automobile exhaust accounts for the largest source of benzene pollution in the general environment.

Statement 2 is correct: Active and passive exposure to tobacco smoke is also a significant source of exposure to benzene pollution.

Statement 3 is correct: Wood burning is also a source of benzene pollution.

questionText: In India, the use of carbofuran, methyl parathion, phorate and triazophos is viewed with apprehension. These chemicals are used as
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Carbofuran, methyl parathion, phorate and triazophos are used as pesticides in Agriculture. The use of these pesticides is banned in India as these pesticides are highly hazardous with the potential to cause severe health problems such as hormonal changes, carcinogenic, neurotoxic, reproductive and developmental health effects as well as environmental impacts such as toxic to bees.

questionText: In the context of which one of the following are the terms 'pyrolysis and plasma gasification' mentioned?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Waste-to-Energy (WtE) technologies consist of any waste treatment process that creates energy in the form of electricity, heat, or transport fuels (e.g. diesel) from a waste source. Pyrolysis is a common technique used to convert plastic waste into energy, in the form of solid, liquid and gaseous fuels. Plasma gasification technology treats wastes and generates syngas to produce electricity or heat.

questionText:
Consider the following:
1. Carbon monoxide
2. Methane
3. Ozone
4. Sulphur dioxide
Which of the above are released into the atmosphere due to the burning of crop/biomass residue?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Burning of crop residues/biomass emits gases like sulphur dioxide (SO2), oxides of nitrogen (NOx), carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO), black carbon (BC), organic carbon (OC), methane (CH4), volatile organic compounds (VOC), non-methane hydrocarbons (NMHCs), ozone (O3), and aerosols, etc which affect the global atmospheric chemistry and climate.

questionText:
Consider the following statements:
1. Agricultural soils release nitrogen oxides into the environment.
2. Cattle release ammonia into the environment.
3. The poultry industry releases reactive nitrogen compounds into the environment.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: All three statements are correct. Agricultural soils contribute to over 70% of N2O emissions from India. Cattle account for 80% of the ammonia production. The poultry industry releases reactive nitrogen compounds and is anticipated to increase by almost 250% by 2030.

questionText: Why is there a great concern about the 'microbeads' that are released into the environment?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Microbeads are small, solid, manufactured plastic particles that are less than 5mm in diameter and do not degrade or dissolve in water. They are not captured by most wastewater treatment systems and can end up in rivers, lakes and oceans. These tiny plastics persist in the environment and have a damaging effect on marine life, the environment and human health.

options.text: They are considered harmful to marine ecosystems.
They are considered to cause skin cancer in children.
They are small enough to be absorbed by crop plants in irrigated fields.
They are often found to be used as food adulterants.

questionText:
Which of the following is/are the possible consequence/s of heavy sand mining in riverbeds?
1. Decreased salinity in the river
2. Pollution of groundwater
3. Lowering of the water-table
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Heavy sand mining in riverbeds can lead to pollution of groundwater and lowering of the water table. The sediment in the mining site, if it contains toxic material due to long time accumulation, will cause groundwater pollution. The riverbed becomes dry due to exposure to solar radiation, decreasing the surface and groundwater, causing a lowering of the water tables.

questionText:
The average marks of 100 students are given to be 40.
It was found later that marks of one student were 53 which were misread as 83.
The corrected mean marks are
subject: Quantitative ability

questionText:
In the context of solving pollution problems, what is/are the advantage/advantages of the bioremediation technique?
1. It is a technique for cleaning up pollution by enhancing the same biodegradation process that occurs in nature.
2. Any contaminant with heavy metals such as cadmium and lead can be readily and completely treated by bioremediation using microorganisms.
3. Genetic engineering can be used to create microorganisms specifically designed for bioremediation.
Select the correct option using the given code below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Bioremediation enhances the same biodegradation processes that occur in nature to clean up pollution. However, not all contaminants, especially heavy metals like cadmium and lead, are readily treated through bioremediation. Genetic engineering can be used to create microorganisms specifically designed for bioremediation, enhancing their degradative capabilities for various chemical contaminants.

questionText: Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) is a standard criterion for
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) is a standard criterion for pollution assay in aquatic ecosystems. It is the amount of dissolved oxygen needed by bacteria in decomposing the organic wastes present in water. The higher value of BOD indicates the low dissolved oxygen content of water, which is directly related to the increasing input of organic wastes.

options.text: Measuring oxygen levels in the blood
Computing oxygen levels in forest ecosystems
Assessing oxygen levels in high-altitude regions

questionText:
In the cities of our country, which among the following atmospheric gases are normally considered in calculating the value of the Air Quality Index?
1. Carbon dioxide
2. Carbon monoxide
3. Nitrogen dioxide
4. Sulphur dioxide
5. Methane
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The Air Quality Index (AQI) in India considers eight pollutants for calculation: PM10, PM2.5, Nitrogen dioxide (NO2), Sulphur dioxide (SO2), Carbon monoxide (CO), Ozone (O3), Ammonia (NH3), and Lead (Pb). Among the options given, carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, and sulphur dioxide are included in AQI calculations.

questionText:
Brominated flame retardants are used in many household products like mattresses and upholstery. Why is there some concern about their use?
1. They are highly resistant to degradation in the environment.
2. They are able to accumulate in humans and animals.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Brominated flame retardants (BFRs) are highly resistant to degradation in the environment and can persist for long periods. They can also enter the food chain and tend to bioaccumulate in living organisms, including humans and animals. BFRs have raised significant concerns for their persistence, bioaccumulation, and potential toxicity to the ecological environment and human health.

questionText:
There is some concern regarding the nanoparticles of some chemical elements that are used by the industry in the manufacture of various products. Why?
1. They can accumulate in the environment and contaminate water and soil.
2. They can enter the food chains.
3. They can trigger the production of free radicals.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Nanoparticles can accumulate in the environment and contaminate water and soil, from here they enter the food chain and bioaccumulate. Materials that by themselves are not very harmful could be toxic if they are inhaled in the form of nanoparticles. The effects of inhaled nanoparticles in the body may include lung inflammation and heart problems. Most of these are due to the high surface-to-volume ratio, which can make the particles very reactive or catalytic and make them trigger the production of free radicals. For example, Iron oxide nanoparticles act as a catalyst for the degradation of hydrogen peroxide into free radicals.

questionText:
Which of the following are some important pollutants released by the steel industry in India?
1. Oxides of sulphur
2. Oxide of nitrogen
3. Carbon monoxide
4. Carbon dioxide
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The steel industry releases large amounts of pollutants into the air during all its processes be it while handling raw material, producing iron and steel, or disposing of solid waste. The main pollutants are particulate matter, oxides of sulphur and nitrogen, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide. As per the TERI report in 2020, carbon dioxide emissions from the steel industry are projected to jump to 837 million tons over the next three decades from 242 million tons now as India's demand for steel more than quadruples to about 490 million tons.

questionText:
Which of the following can be found as pollutants in the drinking water in some parts of India?
1. Arsenic
2. Sorbitol
3. Fluoride
4. Formaldehyde
5. Uranium
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Groundwater quality data generated during various scientific studies and groundwater quality monitoring indicate that the groundwater in major parts of the country is potable. However, some parts of various states are contaminated by Salinity, Arsenic, Fluoride, Iron, Nitrate, and Heavy metals beyond the permissible limits of BIS. Moreover, an international study has found widespread Uranium contamination in groundwater from aquifers in 16 Indian states.

questionText: Photochemical smog is a resultant of the reaction among
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The main components of the photochemical smog resulting from the action of sunlight on unsaturated hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides produced by automobiles and factories. Photochemical smog has a high concentration of oxidising agents and is, therefore, called as oxidising smog. The common components of photochemical smog are ozone (O3), nitric oxide (NO2), acrolein, formaldehyde and peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN).

options.text: NO2, O3 and peroxyacetyl nitrate in the presence of sunlight
CO, O2 and peroxyacetyl nitrate in the presence of sunlight
CO, CO2 and NO2 at low temperature
high concentration of NO2, O3 and CO in the evening

questionText:
Consider the following statements:
Chlorofluorocarbons, known as ozone depleting substances, are used
1. In the production of plastic foams
2. In the production of tubeless tyres
3. In cleaning certain electronic components
4. As pressurizing agents in aerosol cans
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Chlorofluorocarbons, known as ozone-depleting substances, are used in the production of plastic foams, in cleaning electronic components and as pressurizing agents in aerosol cans.

questionText:
Lead, ingested or inhaled, is a health hazard. After the addition of lead to petrol has been banned, what still are the sources of lead poisoning?
1. Smelting units
2. Pens and pencils
3. Paints
4. Hair oils and cosmetics
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: After the addition of lead to petrol has been banned, but still lead is found in many sources including lead-based paints (paint on the walls of old houses and toys), art supplies, contaminated dust, lead crystal glassware, ammunition, ceramic glazes, jeweller, and traditional medicines. Besides this, the most common route of lead exposure is caused by lead smelting, which is through inhalation or ingestion of lead dust, particles, or exhaust from the burning process. Workers in the smelting factories are particularly at risk, as they can be exposed to prolonged and direct inhalation of gaseous emissions and dust.

questionText:
There is a concern over the increase in harmful algal blooms in the seawater of India. What could be the causative factors for this phenomenon?
1. Discharge of nutrients from the estuaries.
2. Run-off from the land during the monsoon.
3. Upwelling in the seas.
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Algal blooms are the result of an excess of nutrients, particularly some phosphates. Algal blooms are caused by a major influx of nutrient-rich runoff into a water body, programs to treat wastewater, reduce the overuse of fertilisers in agriculture and reduce the bulk flow of runoff can be effective for reducing severe algal blooms at river mouths, estuaries, and the ocean directly in front of the river's mouth. Monsoon and Climate Change might affect rainfall patterns, leading to alternating periods of drought and intense storms. This can cause more nutrient runoff into water bodies, feeding more algal blooms. The process by which winds push surface water offshore and deep water moves towards the coast, bringing nutrients from the ocean floor to the surface is Coastal upwelling. Climate change is expected to alter the timing and intensity of coastal upwelling. Along the East and west coast of India, excess nutrients delivered by upwelling might lead to more algal blooms.

questionText:
Consider the following:
1. Carbon dioxide
2. Oxides of nitrogen
3. Oxides of Sulphur
Which of the above is/are the emission/emissions from coal combustion at thermal power plants?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: The main emissions from coal combustion at thermal power plants are carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulphur oxides (SOx), chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), carbonaceous material, and air-borne inorganic particles such as fly ash, also known as suspended particulate matter (SPM) and other trace gas species. Carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, and chlorofluorocarbons are greenhouse gases.

questionText: The formation of ozone holes in the Antarctic Region has been a cause of concern. What could be the reason for the formation of this hole?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Ozone layer depletion is the gradual thinning of the earth's ozone layer in the upper atmosphere caused due to the release of chemical compounds containing gaseous bromine or chlorine from industries or other human activities. Ozone depletion occurs when ozone molecules in the upper atmosphere are destroyed by chemical reactions with halogen gases, such as chlorine. To form chlorine the nitric acid in polar stratospheric clouds reacts with chlorofluorocarbon carbon (CFCs), which catalyses the photochemical destruction of ozone. In the winter months, Cold conditions above Antarctica encourage the formation of extremely cold, high-altitude clouds.

options.text: Presence of prominent tropospheric turbulence; and inflow of chlorofluorocarbons
Presence of prominent polar front and stratospheric clouds; and inflow of chlorofluorocarbons
Absence of polar front and stratospheric clouds; and inflow of methane and chlorofluorocarbons
Increased temperature at polar region due to global warming

questionText: Recently, "oilzapper" was in the news. What is it?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: 'Oilzapper' is a bio-remediation technique involving the use of 'oil zapping' bacteria to clean up oil spills in the sea. It is considered as the most eco-friendly technology for the remediation of oil sludge. Oilzapper refers to a mixture of five microbial strains that are capable of eating up oil, they take in the pollutants and give out carbon dioxide without producing any harmful residues. Oilzapper feeds on hydrocarbon compounds present in crude oil and the hazardous hydrocarbon waste generated by oil refineries, known as Oil Sludge and converts them into harmless CO2 and water.

options.text: It is an eco-friendly technology for the remediation of oily sludge and oil spills.
It is the latest technology developed for undersea oil exploration.
It is a genetically engineered high biofuel-yielding maize variety.
It is the latest technology to control the accidentally caused flames from oil wells.

questionText:
With reference to "Gucchi" sometimes mentioned in the news, consider the following statements :
1. It is a fungus.
2. It grows in some Himalayan forest areas.
3. It is commercially cultivated in the Himalayan foothills of north-eastern India.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Statement 1 is correct: Guchhi mushroom is a species of fungus in the family Morchellaceae of the Ascomycota. One of the most sought-after edible mushrooms, guchhi is known for its spongy, honeycombed head and savoury flavour but all of that comes at a high price.\n\nStatement 2 is correct and Statement 3 is not correct: Apart from its flavour, guchhi also owes its high price to the challenges in cultivation. The mushrooms cannot be cultivated commercially and grow in conifer forests across temperature regions, and the foothills in Himachal Pradesh, Uttaranchal, and Jammu and Kashmir. And it takes months for villagers to collect enough of these mushrooms, dry them and bring them to the market.

questionText: Which of the following is not a bird?
subject: Environment & ecology and disaster management
explanation: Option (a) is correct: Golden Mahseer is a fish, whose scientific name is Tor putitora. Mahseer roughly translates as mahi – fish and sher – tiger, and hence is also referred as tiger among fish. It is a large cyprinid and known to be the toughest among freshwater sport fish.

questionText:
Consider the following statements:
1. Moringa (drumstick trees) is a leguminous evergreen trees.
2. The Tamarind tree is endemic to South Asia.
3. In India, most of the tamarind is collected as minor forest produce.
